results.title: Not one less = Yi ge dou bu neng shao
results.creator_credit: Zhang Yimou, Zhao Yu, Beijing New Picture Film Company and Guangxi Film Studio
results.brief_description: Directed by Yimou Zhang, the rural drama “Not one less” is a study in poverty and the determination of one teenage girl. Wei Minzhi is a barely educated thirteen-year-old, who takes on a job teaching young children at an impoverished village school. As the regular teacher leaves he promises Wei bonus pay if, upon his return, all the students are still in school. Inexperienced and overwhelmed, but relentlessly stubborn, Wei faces ingratitude and her own misery as she grapples with the recalcitrant students. When one boy is sent to work in the city, where he lives on the street, Wei pursues him. Once there Wei is overwhelmed by the crowds, bustling street life and enormity of the task of finding a young boy amid the vast city and innumerable homeless children who reside there. Here Zhang steers away from the lush melodramas, such as “Raise the red lantern”, “Red sorghum” and “Shanghai Triad”, in favour of a sparse aesthetic that speaks of the plight of rural Chinese, portraying village life decimated by the commercialisation of China.

results.title: Fear and loathing in Las Vegas
results.creator_credit: Terry Gilliam, Laila Nabulsi, Patrick Cassavetti, Stephen Nemeth, Rhino Films, Shark Production and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Terry Gilliam’s surreal depiction of Hunter S. Thompson’s classic 1971 novel “Fear and loathing in Las Vegas: A savage journey into the heart of the American dream”, encapsulates sportswriter Raoul Duke (Thompson’s alter-ego) descent into a drug induced frenzy on a wild road trip with his friend and lawyer Oscar Zeta Acosta (Benicio del Toro). This story established the term ‘Gonzo journalism’ as Duke travels from California to Las Vegas to report on the Mint 400 Desert Motorcycle race, with a suitcase filled with an assortment of drugs. This illegal stash, heartily consumed, influenced the crazy antics of the bumbling duo and provided an insight into the decline of the 1960s peace and love generation. Johnny Depp’s stunning portrayal of the infamous journalist and writer, is a tour-de-force of acid trip induced hallucinations and paranoia that creates a nightmarish world filled with reptilian monsters, circus dwarfs and morphing hotel rooms. Terry Gilliam’s visually stimulating frenetic hand-held style graphically conveys confronting images of psychedelic induced episodes by the main characters who flail around in murky baths brandishing knives and picking up underage girls. The film has been described as hilarious, disturbing and magical. Guest appearances by Cameron Diaz, Toby Maguire, Harry Dean Stanton and Christina Ricci.

results.title: The World according to John Coltrane
results.creator_credit: Robert Palmer, Toby Byron, Multiprises and Taurus Film
results.brief_description: John Coltrane (1927-67) was one of the most influential jazz musicians and saxophonists of the twentieth century. Brought up experiencing gospel and rhythm and blues, Coltrane was revered for his unique style, incredible commitment to, and passion for jazz. Initially Coltrane joined Miles Davis’ band, before forming his own four-piece that included Elvin Jones, Jimmy Garrison, McCoy Tyner and later Eric Dolphy and Pharoah Sanders. Coltrane also performed with Dizzy Gillespie, playing Bebop, and legendary pianist Thelonius Monk. As well as containing live footage, this work probes Coltrane’s interest in the science of sound, the philosophy of music espoused within many Eastern cultures, ideas to which Coltrane was drawn as he expressed spiritual issues through his art. Exploration into notions of Eastern modality resulted in extended solos, which influenced jazz, contemporary classical music and even rock. This documentary examines Coltrane’s music in the 1960s as a reflection of the massive changes wrought within American society, particularly in regards to incendiary race relations. Features the voice of Alice Coltrane, discussing her husband and the links between his spirituality and music, and interviews with various friends and colleagues, including Roscoe Mitchell, Rashied Ali, Tommy Flanagan, Jimmy Heath, Wayne Shorter and La Monte Young. Includes performances of his famed re-working of “My favourite things” (from The Sound of music), “Naima”, “Giant steps” (with Miles Davis), “So what” and “Reverend King Alabama” - a tribute to Martin Luther King.

results.title: Ponette
results.creator_credit: Jacques Doillon, Alain Sarde and Arrow Productions
results.brief_description: Powerful and touching film portrayal of a four-year-old girl’s struggle to understand the meaning of death after she loses her mother in a car accident in which she herself is also injured. Following her mother’s funeral, Ponette is left by her father in the care of her aunt, where she and her two cousins are largely left to resolve their confusion and loss on their own. Told by her aunt about Jesus’ resurrection, Ponette patiently awaits her mother’s return, a reunion she dreams about incessantly. Related entirely from the perspective of the young girl, the film is dominated by the performance of Victorie Thivisol who won best actress at the 1996 Venice Film Festival for her role. Doillon’s success in entering the mind of a child grappling with the concept of death, stemmed from his writing and auditioning process. He established a workshop for four- and five-year-olds selected during a comprehensive audition process and worked for six months with the children, acting out scenarios and creating sketches, asking their opinions on a variety of subjects and adapting his script from their dialogue. This unique collaboration - giving the children a full range of expression - solidifies the film’s emotional base. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Ciao! Manhattan
results.creator_credit: David Weisman, John Palmer, Robert Margouleff and Court Pictures
results.brief_description: Initially filmed in 1965 “Ciao! Manhattan” was an experimental film made on a miniscule budget with a counter-culture underground tone, starring the ‘superstar’ and ‘it’ girl of the Andy Warhol Factory scene - Edie Sedgwick. Filmmakers John Palmer and David Weisman, aware that their 1960s footage did not amount to a comprehensive narrative, decided to continue filming several years later, cobbling their 1960s work together with new scenes, introducing the story of Butch - a 1970s drifter who picks up a topless and disoriented woman (Susan) hitchhiking. Delivering Susan to her eccentric mother’s mansion, Susan occupies an empty swimming pool and surrounded by Edie paraphernalia, the couple relive Susan/Edie’s heyday. Edie essentially plays herself as Susan, a beautiful rebellious heiress who models for Vogue, hangs with the famous artists and iconoclasts of her time and represents the look and mood of the silver sixties. In the seventies portion of the film she is past her prime, damaged by excessive drug intake, reliving her former glory whilst lolling around topless and occasionally making sense. As a conventional feature “Ciao! Manhattan” barely holds together, the disorderly history of its production undermining notions of a cohesive structure. But the story of Edie Sedgwick, encapsulated within the extensive footage of her at both ends of the spectrums of her life, is fascinating. Sedgwick died several months after the production completed. Cast includes: Roger Vadim, Viva, Paul America, Isabel Jewell, Brigid Berlin and Baby Jane Holzer.

results.title: The Cat's meow [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Bogdanovich, Carol Lewis, Dieter Meyer, Julie Baines, Kim Bieber, Bieber + Lewis, CP Medien, Dan Films and Lions Gate Films
results.brief_description: Based on an old Hollywood rumour, “The Cat’s meow” is about William Randolph Hearst, the media magnate infamous in the 1920s for his power and wealth. In this story, “the whisper told most often” as one character puts it, the year is 1924 and Hearst’s private yacht is headed for San Diego, with a dozen guests, a mix of Hollywood power players and ambitious types, aboard. Amid the high profile travellers are Charlie Chaplin, gossip columnist Louella Parsons, actress, and Hearst’s long-term mistress, Marion Davies pioneering film producer and director Thomas Ince and acerbic novelist Elinor Glyn. As the ship sails, the intricate, and at times intimate, relationships between the players are placed under pressure by shifting power plays and the separate agendas of each character. Due to his legendary paranoia, Hearst has placed ‘bugs’ throughout the boat, enabling him to scrutinise, in particular, the relationship of Chaplin and Davies. The most interesting aspect of the film watching the larger than life Chaplin (deftly played by British comedian Eddie Izzard), operate not as a great artist, but as simply a man on the make. Hearst, depicted as a jealous and curmudgeonly buffoon, eavesdropping on his guests and girlfriend, trusting no one, is far more one-dimensional. Also of note is Kirsten Dunst who gives an infectiously joyous portrayal of Davies, a much-maligned comedian of her times. “The Cat’s meow” struggles as a murder mystery, but works well as a prism of 1920s Hollywood when the allure of stars like Chaplin was at a pinnacle, fed by an adoring public.

results.title: The Disorderly orderly
results.creator_credit: Frank Tashlin, Paul Jones and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In his eighth, and final, collaboration with director Frank Tashlin, Jerry Lewis plays Jerome Littlefield, a nurse in a sanatorium whose manic and clumsy antics manage to upset patients and staff alike. Lewis is given free reign here to display his usual brand of silly, goofy and slapstick physical humour. Typically, although Jerome is a sympathetic attendant, he effortlessly manages to derail those he cares for. In one hilarious scene a hypochondriac patient relays her many maladies as Lewis displays her symptoms. Another highlight is a quite mad chase through hilly streets, with an ambulance in pursuit of a freewheeling stretcher (with a stunned patient aboard), ending in a catastrophic encounter with numerous supermarket trolleys. As this comedy is set in a hospital, some salient points are made about systemic corruption and profit margins that increase with a simultaneous decline in care. But quite expectedly, the darker tones of the film are marginalised in favour of comedic set-pieces, consistent with Lewis’ other work, and highlights his talent for physical idiocy and facial expressiveness. Also stars Glenda Farrell, Everett Sloane, Karen Sharpe and Kathleen Freeman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Tashlin, Paul Jones and Paramount Pictures

Another highlight is a quite mad chase through hilly streets, with an ambulance in pursuit of a freewheeling stretcher (with a stunned patient aboard), ending in a catastrophic encounter with numerous supermarket trolleys. As this comedy is set in a hospital, some salient points are made about systemic corruption and profit margins that increase with a simultaneous decline in care. But quite expectedly, the darker tones of the film are marginalised in favour of comedic set-pieces, consistent with Lewis’ other work, and highlights his talent for physical idiocy and facial expressiveness. Also stars Glenda Farrell, Everett Sloane, Karen Sharpe and Kathleen Freeman.
description_for_label: In his eighth, and final, collaboration with director Frank Tashlin, Jerry Lewis plays Jerome Littlefield, a nurse in a sanatorium whose manic and clumsy antics manage to upset patients and staff alike. Lewis is given free reign here to display his usual brand of silly, goofy and slapstick physical humour. Typically, although Jerome is a sympathetic attendant, he effortlessly manages to derail those he cares for. In one hilarious scene a hypochondriac patient relays her many maladies as Lewis displays her symptoms. Another highlight is a quite mad chase through hilly streets, with an ambulance in pursuit of a freewheeling stretcher (with a stunned patient aboard), ending in a catastrophic encounter with numerous supermarket trolleys. As this comedy is set in a hospital, some salient points are made about systemic corruption and profit margins that increase with a simultaneous decline in care. But quite expectedly, the darker tones of the film are marginalised in favour of comedic set-pieces, consistent with Lewis’ other work, and highlights his talent for physical idiocy and facial expressiveness. Also stars Glenda Farrell, Everett Sloane, Karen Sharpe and Kathleen Freeman.

results.title: The Ladies man
results.creator_credit: Jerry Lewis, Paramount Pictures and York Pictures
results.brief_description: This comedy starring Jerry Lewis (his third directorial effort) is set in an all female boarding house, brimming with sex-starved women. Lewis plays Herbert H. Herbert, a university graduate sworn off love whilst mourning the break-up of a relationship, who takes a job as house boy. As well as being in charge of repairs, the fumbling Herbert has to deal with being the lone male presence amid so many nubile beauties. The house itself, a multilayered set built at enormous cost, is an impressive and colourful piece that at times dwarfs the star and the patchy narrative. Typically, several musical interludes pepper the action, allowing for some imaginative moments of dance and song. Characteristically for a Lewis comedy, the talented comedian is given free reign to display his brand of silly, goofy and slapstick physical humour, highlighting his penchant for physical idiocy and facial expressiveness. Cast includes Helen Traubel, Kathleen Freeman, Hope Holiday, Mary Laroche and Madlyn Rhue.

results.title: Artists and models
results.creator_credit: Frank Tashlin, Hal B. Wallis and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In this satirical slapstick comedy Dean Martin plays Rick Todd, a fledging painter who has relocated to New York in search of acclaim. Eugene, Rick’s best friend and housemate also has ambitions, as a children’s writer, but his clumsy antics continuously lose them menial jobs that they land. Despite their misfortunes the impoverished pair dream of greater things, such as food, girls, money and fame. Along the way, the friends woo their luscious neighbours, comic book artist Abigail (Dorothy Malone) and her model, Bessie (Shirley MacLaine). When Abigail resigns after being asked to beef up her storylines with more blood and gore, Rick takes her job, using Eugene’s ecstatic and vivid dreams as material. Eugene dreams up the secret formula for rocket fuel, and enemy agents are soon on his tail. Several musical interludes pepper the film that is alight with sight gags, physical and madcap humour, and despite its largely formulaic approach, is one of the finest Lewis and Martin comedies made as a duo.

results.title: Harry Potter and the chamber of secrets
results.creator_credit: Chris Columbus, David Heyman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The second instalment in the Harry Potter series returns to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, in what is arguably a stronger film than its predecessor, despite belief that the novel on which the film is based, is the weakest in the series. An enchanting musical score and solid animation are supported by strong performances of young actors Daniel Radcliff, Emma Watson and Rupert Grint, who reprise their roles as Harry, Hermione and Ron. Between dealing with cryptic house-elves, flying cars, Quidditch, and attempting to keep one step ahead of the nasty Slytherins, who has time to study? However, when muggle-born students are being attacked, it is once again up to Harry and his friends to save the day. The all-star British cast includes Jason Isaacs as the malicious Lucius Malfoy and Kenneth Branagh as pompous professor Gilderoy Lockhart who join Richard Harris, in one of his final roles, Maggie Smith, Alan Rickman, Robbie Coltrane, John Cleese, Fiona Shaw, Zoe Wanamaker, Julie Walters, John Hurt, Ian Hart, Richard Griffiths and Warwick Davis.
